medium_description_en: Diagnoses HCC based on serum biomarkers in patients with chronic liver disease (CLD).

seo.meta_description_en: The GALAD Model for Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) diagnoses HCC based on serum biomarkers.
seo.keywords_en: Chronic liver disease, CLD, GALAD score, HCC diagnosis

how_to_use.use_case_en: Use in patients with chronic liver disease (CLD).
how_to_use.why_use_en:
• Estimates risk that a CLD patient has HCC using only tumor markers and demographics (i.e., no imaging).
  • AUROC was 0.92 in one validation study (Best 2016).

next_steps.advice_en: Use clinical judgment to determine how closely to surveil patients for HCC.
next_steps.management_en: No guidelines currently exist for thresholds at which to image patients based on GALAD results. One large prospective study suggests patients with AFP ≥10 ng/mL or AFP-L3 ≥5% be imaged with CT or MRI every 3-6 months (Kumada 2011).

about.formula_en:
GALAD Score = -10.08 + 0.09 x A + 1.67 x G + 2.34 log10(AF) + 0.04 x L + 1.33 x log10(D)

Where variables are as follows:

Variable

Value

Gender

0 if female

1 if male

Age

Age, years

AFP-L3

Alpha fetoprotein L3, %

AFP

Alpha fetoprotein, ng/mL

DCP

Des-carboxy-prothrombin, ng/mL
about.more_info_en:
Interpretation:

Probability of concurrent HCC in this CLD patient = exp(Z) / (1 + exp(Z))

Where Z = GALAD Score

Original/Primary Reference.text: Johnson PJ, Pirrie SJ, Cox TF, et al. The detection of hepatocellular carcinoma using a prospectively developed and validated model based on serological biomarkers. Cancer Epidemiol Biomarkers Prev. 2014;23(1):144-53.

Other References.text: Kumada T, Toyoda H, Kiriyama S, et al. Predictive value of tumor markers for hepatocarcinogenesis in patients with hepatitis C virus. J Gastroenterol. 2011;46(4):536-44.

Validation.text: Best J, Bilgi H, Heider D, et al. The GALAD scoring algorithm based on AFP, AFP-L3, and DCP significantly improves detection of BCLC early stage hepatocellular carcinoma. Z Gastroenterol. 2016;54(12):1296-1305.

creator_info.about_en: Philip J. Johnson, MD, FRCP, is a professor in translational oncology at the University of Liverpool. He is also the deputy director of the North West Cancer Research Centre, University of Liverpool. Dr. Johnson’s primary research is focused on diagnosis and prognosis of hepatobiliary and pancreatic cancer.
